content.question:
For a chi-square test for independence with <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> degrees of freedom and a significance level of <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the value of the test statistic was <math alttext="chi squared is approximately equal to 10.497" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>≈</mo><mn>10.497</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The associated <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value was <math alttext="0.1052" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1052</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Assuming all necessary conditions for the chi-square test were met, what type of error is possible?

choices.label: A Type <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> error is possible, because the null hypothesis was rejected.
A Type <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> error is possible, because the null hypothesis was not rejected.
No error is possible, because the correct decision was made.
A Type <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> error is possible, because the null hypothesis was rejected.
A Type <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> error is possible, because the null hypothesis was not rejected.

content.answer: A Type <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> error is possible, because the null hypothesis was not rejected.

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Identify key and relevant information to answer a question or solve a problem.
